snippet: Japan’s government said it intends to stop using nuclear power by the 2030s, marking a major shift from policy goals set before last year’s Fukushima disaster.
abstract: Japan says it will seek to phase out nuclear power by 2040, marking major shift from policy goals set before the Fukushima disaster, but one that falls fall short of promises the government made in wake of disaster; 2040 time frame allows most of the existing reactors to live out their 40-year life span, heading off costly losses for their operators.

byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy contributed reporting from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: Japan’s government said it intends to stop using nuclear power by the 2030s, marking a major shift from policy goals set before last year’s Fukushima disaster.

headline.seo: Japan Will Try to Halt Nuclear Power by the End of the 2030s
headline.main: Japan Sets Policy to Phase Out Nuclear Power Plants by 2040
headline.print_headline: Japan Sets Policy to Phase Out Nuclear Power Plants by 2040
